description: UK C19. From Abaddon, from Middle English, from Late Latin, from Ancient Greek Ἀβαδδών (Abaddṓn, “Abaddon”), from Hebrew אבדון‎ (ābaddōn, “destruction, abyss”), from אבד‎ (ābad, “to be lost, to perish”).

entries.meaning: (archaic, British slang) An informer; a criminal who informs on other criminals to the authorities.
examples: The prisoner, Money Moses, better known among thieves and fences as Moses the abaddon, has been, to my knowledge, for the last twenty years a receiver and dealer in stolen property.
